items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to recent rainfall. Today, Sunday 06/11/2022, is forecast to be a showery day but the lake level at the Lodore gauge is expected to remain relatively constant. Further rain is forecast over this afternoon and into Monday 07/11/2022 and we expect the lake to start to rise from tomorrow morning. Flooding is affecting locations near these rivers and the lake, with low lying land most affected, particularly around the Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 07/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: Flooding is possible at The Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall from 03:30am and 06:30am on Monday 07/11/2022 due to strong southerly winds and large onshore waves. Areas most at risk include The Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall. Spring tides are from Monday 07/11/2022 to Wednesday 09/11/2022 and may result in further alerts being issued. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:00am on 07/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 08:15 AM on 07/11/2022.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected between 08:15 AM and 12:00 PM on 07/11/2022.
We are expecting higher than normal tides up to and including the morning tide of the 9th of November.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 07/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen again on the Upper Wey at Standford, Tilford and Godalming areas as a result of persistent heavy rainfall overnight and today. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected today and tomorrow 07/11/22.
The forecast for tomorrow is for more showers, therefore we expect levels to remain high.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 07/11/22, or if the situation changes.

Heavy rain has fallen over west London today, Sunday 6 November. 
River levels on the River Pinn are high in the Uxbridge area. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible today. Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur. 
We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 
Further heavy showers are possible this afternoon and this is likely to keep the river levels high.  River levels in Pinner and Hillingdon are also likely to rise again. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages. 
We will update this message at 8pm today or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of persistent heavy rainfall overnight and today 06/11/22. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected tomorrow 07/11/22, especially in the Free Prae Road area. 
The forecast for tonight is relatively dry with some showers tomorrow, therefore we expect levels to fall but remail above the threshold for flood alert.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 07/11/22, or if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 09:15 AM on 07/11/2022.
Areas most at risk include Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle.
Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected between 08:30 AM and 10:00 AM on 07/11/2022.
We are expecting higher than normal tides up to and including the morning tide 8th of November 2022.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 07/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Monday morning's tide at 09:53 on 07/11/2022 and 11:40 on 07/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.41 m. The total forecast tide is 4.27 metres Chart Datum (2.27 mAOD) at Beaulieu. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood the garden of the mill house on the downstream side of the Mill Pond. It will also flow across Palace Lane and the B3056 (Hatchet Lane), making it temporarily more difficult for traffic to access the village. Flood water in Palace Lane could be up to 0.2m deep. At 22:06 on Monday (07/11/2022)‚ the tide and flood impacts will be similar to Monday morning. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. For safety, please take care if walking through Beaulieu. The incoming tide will flood roads quickly. At Hatchet Lane, driving through flood water increases flood risk to property. Please avoid using this road. We will update this message by 14:00 on 07/11/2022.

Monday morning's tide at 10:21 on 07/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.36 m. The total forecast tide is 5.24 metres Chart Datum (2.51 mAOD) at Portsmouth. For 1 hour either side of high water, levels will be high at South Street and Queen Street Emsworth. The Ship Inn car park at Langstone will flood. Water will flow into the road at Langstone High Street, although flood depths will be relatively shallow, and flooding will only cause impacts nearest to the harbour front. At 22:34 on Monday (07/11/2022)‚ the tide will be slightly lower than Monday mornings, but impacts will be similar. We'll issue further advice. In Emsworth, we will lower levels in the Mill Pond. If you have it, and live directly on the harbour front, please install flood protection 1 hour before high tide. We will update this message by 14:00 on 07/11/2022.

Monday morning's tide at 10:15 on 07/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.41 m. The total forecast tide is 4.81 metres Chart Datum (2.22 mAOD) at Cowes. For 1 hour either side of high water, very minor impact flooding will affect some sea front roads, esplanades and car parks across the island. Water will be high up slipways in Cowes, affecting Medina Road and the floating bridge. In East Cowes, sea water forced up through drains may cause very minor impacts to the road at Albany Road. At 22:15 on 07/11/2022‚ the tide and flood impacts will be similar to Monday morning (07/11/2022). We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. At Medina Road, near the Floating Bridge, the tide may rise to be only 0.1m below the top of the front door steps. As a precautionary measure, and if you have it, we recommend that flood protection is installed at Medina Road 1 hour before high tide. We will update this message by 14:00 on 07/11/2022.

Monday morning's tide at 09:53 on 07/11/2022 and 11:40 on 07/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.41 m. The total forecast tide is 5.20 metres Chart Datum (2.46 mAOD) at Southampton. For 1 hour either side of high water, very minor impact flooding will affect the lower floor level of Eling Tide Mill and boat yards at Bursledon. Road and car park flooding may occur at The Quay in Hamble, Magazine Lane at Marchwood and Shore Road in Hythe. At 22:06 on Monday (07/11/2022)‚ the tide and flood impacts will be similar to Monday morning. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid parking in low lying coastal car parks and plan driving routes to avoid the roads listed in this message. We will update this message by 14:00 on 07/11/2022.

Monday morning's tide at 09:53 on 07/11/2022 and 11:40 on 07/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.41 m. The total forecast tide is 5.20 metres Chart Datum (2.46 mAOD) at Southampton. For 1.5 hours either side of high water, levels in the lower River Itchen will increase as the incoming tide prevents water from flowing out to sea. Footpath flooding will affect some areas of Riverside Park. The pub car park at Mansbridge, may see minor impact flooding for a short period of time. Any flood depth would be relatively shallow. The tide will not flood property or the A27. At 22:06 on Monday (07/11/2022)‚ the tide and flood impacts will be similar to Monday morning. We'll issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast. As a very precautionary measure, please consider closing the defence gates around the pub. We will update this message by 14:00 on 07/11/2022.

The River Uck is still very high and currently rising. Nearly half a month's rainfall has fallen on Sunday. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and be close to riverside properties through Buxted, near the White Hart pub, Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, Uckfield as well as Isfield MIll and near Isfield Bridge. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect the Roller Mill, Mill Lane, River Way, Bridge Cottage and Bell Walk, Uckfield. Most of the rain has now cleared to the east, but isolated showers are possible Sunday evening, continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall in Buxted by 20:30 06/11/2022, and 23:00 in Uckfield and 04:00 07/11/2022 in Isfield, returning nearer to normal Monday afternoon. We predict river levels could end up a little lower than Thursday. Please keep flood protection products installed in Buxted and Isfield, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 07/11/2022.

floodArea.county: Barnet, Enfield, Essex, Greater London, Haringey, Hertfordshire, Redbridge, Waltham Forest
floodArea.riverOrSea: Ching Brook, Cobbins Brook, Nazeing Brook, Pymmes Brook, Salmons Brook, Turkey Brook, Small River Lee, Rags Brook, Trinity Marsh Ditch

items.message:
Heavy rain has fallen over North London and Hertfordshire today, Sunday 6th November. 

River levels are rising in the Waltham Forest, Waltham Abbey, Waltham Cross, Barnet, Nazeing, Enfield, Chingford, Edmonton, Cheshunt and Tottenham areas. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible this afternoon and evening. Flooding from surface water could also occur. 

Further heavy rain is possible this afternoon. We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages. 
We will update this message at 8pm today or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Colne and Radlett Brook
items.message:
Heavy rain has fallen over south Hertfordshire this morning, Sunday 6th November. River levels on the Upper River Colne and other rivers and streams in the area are rising, particularly in Colney Heath.  

There is likely to be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river today.  Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur. However, property flooding is not currently expected.

Rivers are likely to stay high for much of the day, with further heavy showers possible. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff on standby to attend to any blockages in the river.
This message will be updated at 8pm or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Brent from Hendon to Brentford

floodArea.county: Barnet, Brent, Ealing, Greater London, Hounslow

items.message:
Heavy rain has fallen over London today, Sunday 6 November. 
River levels in the River Brent in the Greenford area are rising. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible today. Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur. 
We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 
Further heavy showers are possible through the day, with the river remaining high. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages. 
We will update this message at 8pm today or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain on Thursday. Levels are rising at Forest Row, Summerford Bridge, near Withyham and at Colliers land Bridge near Ashurst. The internal flooding of property is not expected.  Patchy rain is due this morning and heavier rainfall is due late afternoon, Sunday 6 November 2022 and so this Flood Alert will be maintained throughout the weekend. 

Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly around Forest Row, Ashurst and Penshurst and around Balls Green at Ashurst. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Sunday 6 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Mole, Ifield Brook, Gatwick Stream and Burstow Stream
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ifield Brook, River Mole, Gatwick Stream, Burstow Stream

items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 4:00 pm today until Monday night 7/11/22. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours until the afternoon of Monday 7/11/22 and we expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday morning 8/11/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the river. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.

items.description: River Teise area from Lamberhurst to Goudhurst
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 5pm and 9pm today, Sunday 6th November 2022.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Teise, particularly in Lamberhurst.   

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and we are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.  

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 8am on Monday 7th November 2022, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is still very high and currently rising. Nearly half a month's rainfall has fallen on Sunday. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and be close to riverside properties. From 20:00 06/11/2022, flooding could affect properties at Mock Bridge near Shermanbury. Most of the rain has now cleared to the east, but isolated showers are possible Sunday evening, continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall at Mock Bridge by 05:00 Monday 07/11/2022. but is unlikely to return nearer to normal until Tuesday. River levels will likely peak at a similar height to Thursday. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 07/11/2022.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, almost half a month’s rain (44mm) has been recorded at Wroxhall. Water will be affecting low lying-land, cycle tracks and footpaths. Out of bank flooding is expected at Langbridge. At Alverstone, the river will be close to the top of the bank. Property flooding is not expected. At Sandown, minor flood impacts will continue to affect Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while river levels are high. This evening (06/11/2022) and through the night, showers are forecast. At Alverstone, the river will rise until around 22:00 (06/11/2022). At Sandown, the river will not peak until tomorrow morning. From Monday to Wednesday, rain is forecast on each day. This could cause the river to rise and fall through this period. We are operating Bembridge sluice to manage levels across Brading marshes. Please ensure products used to protect gardens and property are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 10:00 on Monday 07/11/2022.

The River Ouse is high and still rising following Sunday's rain. Flooding will continue to affect fields, gardens and rural roads near and including Sloop Lane, Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. From 21:00 06/11/2022, water will approach the Anchor Inn and properties at Barcombe Mills. Barcombe Mills Road could be impassable. Most of the rain has now cleared to the east, but isolated showers are possible Sunday evening, continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall around 23:00 06/11/2022 near Ardingly, but not until 07:00 07/11/2022 in Barcombe. River levels in Barcombe could be higher than normal until midweek. We think the river will peak a little lower than Thursday. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 07/11/2022.

items.description: The upper Stour and surrounding tributaries
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no significant rainfall overnight into tomorrow, but showers will continue into next week. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

The Bull River in Hellingly and the Cuckmere River in Alfriston are still very high and currently rising. From 20:00 06/11/2022, property flooding could possibly affect locations near North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. From 21:00 06/11/2022 property flooding could also affect Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road Hellingly. Elsewhere, where other rivers are falling, flood impacts should slowly reduce at Hammer Lane near Cowbeech, Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm and Mill Lane, Hellingly. Most of the rain has now cleared to the east, but isolated showers are possible Sunday evening, continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall in Hellingly by 01:00 07/11/2022, and 11:00 07/11/2022 in Alfriston, but might not return to normal until Tuesday. Levels in Alfriston could end up higher than Friday. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 07/11/2022.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain on Thursday. Levels are now rising gradually at all locations in the Rother valley. The internal flooding of property is not expected. Patchy rain is due this morning and heavier rainfall is due late afternoon, Sunday 6 November 2022 and so this Flood Alert will be maintained throughout the weekend. 

Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly in the Crowhurst Bridge area, around Shrub Lane and along the river Rother, particularly around Robertsbridge. We are ready to use the flood defence scheme at Robertsbridge if required. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation, and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Sunday 6 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels remain high in the Leatherhead and Cobham areas. The risk of flooding to roads and low lying land remains for today 06/11/2022.
Further rainfall is expected today and overnight into Monday 07/11/2022.
Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please remain aware of your local situation.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 07/11/2022.

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur
items.message: The River Adur is high and rising. In the last 36 hours, nearly half a month's rain (33mm) has been recorded at Cowfold. From 20:00 Sunday 06/11/2022 flooding will affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding will also affect properties near Mock Bridge and their gardens. Most of the rain has now cleared to the east, but isolated showers are possible Sunday evening, continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall at Mock Bridge by 05:00 Monday 07/11/2022. but is unlikely to return nearer to normal until Tuesday. River levels will likely peak at a similar height to Thursday. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 07/11/2022.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas remains likely over the next few hours and into tomorrow, Monday 7th November. The River Wid is rising steadily in response to recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College. The weather forecast is for some showers, clearing by this evening. The forecast is for further unsettled spells over the next few days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Monday 7th November.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain on Thursday. River levels are rising at locations between Yalding and Allington Lock, including Maidstone. Internal flooding of property is not expected.  Patchy rain is due this morning and heavier rainfall is due late afternoon, Sunday 6 November 2022 and so this Flood Alert will be maintained throughout the weekend. 

Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly riverside areas of Maidstone and along the River Medway. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Sunday 6 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River is high and rising. In the last 36 hours nearly half a month's rain (45mm) has been recorded at Cowbeech. From 21:00 06/11/2022 flooding will affect fields, rural roads, gardens, and properties including The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, and properties near North Street, Willows Car Park and River Lane, Alfriston. Access along Litlington Road may be restricted by flood water. Most of the rain has now cleared to the east, but isolated showers are possible Sunday evening, continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall by 08:00 07/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until Wednesday. River levels could end up similar to, or slightly higher than Friday. Flood water can be deep and dangerous, please take care if walking near the river in Alfriston. Please plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 07/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain on Thursday. Levels are rising gently in Edenbridge, Hever and at Vexour and are forecast to rise in the Lingfield and Haxted Mill areas. Minor flood impacts are expected. The internal flooding of property is not expected. Further heavy rain is forecast today, Sunday 6 November 2022 through to Monday 7 November 2022. Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Water Lane and Haxted Road. 

We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. 

This message will be updated by 8pm on Sunday 6 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Scrase Bridge and West Common Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Scrase Bridge Stream, West Common Stream

items.message: The Scrasebridge and West Common Streams are still higher than normal, but significantly lower than Sunday morning. Further heavy showers are possible Sunday afternoon, and through Monday and Tuesday too. The Scrasebridge and West Common Streams will rise again following rainfall. Minor flood impacts could still return to Meadow Drive, Bridge Road, West Common Road, Hickmans Lane and Blackthorns this afternoon, while river levels are elevated. However, with less rain currently in the forecast than was measured earlier, we believe river levels should not rise as high as they have been Sunday morning. We'll review this Flood Alert Sunday evening 06/11/2022, when there should be less flood risk. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We are routinely clearing debris from grilles through Lindfield, including the Builders Centre and Witch Inn, to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk We will update this message by 22:00 06/11/2022.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Littlemead Brook, Cranleigh Waters, Hascombe Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have increased in Cranleigh on the Littlemead Brook and Cranleigh Waters as a result of persistent heavy rainfall overnight and throughout today. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected tonight and tomorrow 07/11/22.
The forecast for tomorrow is drier, however we expect levels to remain high for the next few days.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 07/11/22, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Ravensbourne area in the London Boroughs of Lewisham, Bromley, Greenwich and Croydon
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Bromley, Croydon, Greater London, Greenwich, Lewisham

items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads, low lying land and gardens close to the river Ravensbourne is expected between 11:00 am and 17:00 pm today, 06/11/22. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point but we will update this message as the situation changes. 
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday morning 8/11/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and clearing trash screens.
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated  in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ingrebourne at Harold Park and Hornchurch
items.message:
Heavy rain has fallen over London this morning, Sunday 6th November. Levels in the River Ingrebourne are rising in the Harold Park and Hornchurch areas. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible today. Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur. 

We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

Further heavy rain is possible through the day. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages. 

We will update this message at 8pm today or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Darent from Westerham to Dartford
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 3:00 pm today until the early hours of tomorrow morning. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 36 hours until the evening of Monday 7/11/22.  We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday morning 8/11/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the river. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

The Western Rother is high and rising. In the last 24 hours 30mm of rain has been recorded at Liss. This is a lot in a short period. From 18:00 06/11/2022 flooding will affect fields, gardens, rural roads and approach properties at Lodsbridge, near Selham as well as Fittleworth Mill, and nearby properties in Fittleworth. From 15:00 06/11/2022 river levels will be high and close to the road at The Wharf, Midhurst. Properties on the Lod could also be affected, including near Lickfold Bridge, Highstead Lane and at Halfway Bridge. Only minimal impacts are currently expected between Liss and Stedham. More showers are possible Sunday afternoon, with wet weather continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall by 05:00 07/11/2022 at Lodsbridge near Selham but will be higher than normal until midweek. River levels are expected to peak higher than Thursday. Early actions to reduce potential impacts with property flood resilience at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 06/11/2022

The Langney Haven is high and rising. In the last 24 hours 40mm of rain has been recorded at Folkington. Which is a lot in a short period. From 14:00 06/11/2022, flooding could affect gardens of Langney Green, and potentially approaching properties at Langney Green too. Fields and parkland including Shinewater Park could also be affected. Most of the rain has now cleared to the east, but another 10mm of rain could fall in showers Sunday afternoon, with wet weather continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall by 21:00 Sunday 06/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until at least midweek. River levels could end up a little higher than on Friday. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed at Langney Green, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Fence Bridge to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 22:00 06/11/2022.

The Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven are high and rising. In the last 24 hours 25mm of rain has been recorded at Powdermill, which is a lot in a short period. From 15:30 06/11/2022, flooding will affect fields, Crowhurst recreation ground and rural roads. It is possible, but currently thought unlikely that flood water could approach a small number of riverside properties in Crowhurst on Forewood Lane and properties between the Plough public house and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill. Water will also affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Most of the rain has now cleared to the east, but another 10mm of rain could fall in showers Sunday afternoon, with wet weather continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall by 22:00 06/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until Monday afternoon. River levels could end up a little higher than Thursday and Friday. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 06/11/2022.

Sunday afternoon's tide at 17:52 PM is higher than normal due to strong  westerly force 7 winds and large waves.
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during the coming tide.
Waves are forecast to overtop coastal defences at the Severn Estuary at Severn Beach including New Passage and Pilning..
Flooding is possible at the Severn Estuary at Severn Beach including New Passage and Pilning either side of the high 
 tide 17:52 PM on 06/11/2022.
After this tide as the winds strength reduces , so no further impacts are expected.
We are closing locks and flood gates in the area.
We will remove this message by 09:00 AM on 07/11/2022.

Monday morning's tide at 10:30 on 07/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 7 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.22 m. The total forecast tide is 6.16 metres Chart Datum (3.11 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, small amounts of water will flood land and fields at Climping. Waves will overtop the sea front, directing water westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards properties on Climping Street. Water may pond near property and in Climping Street Car Park. Very similar tide, weather and flood impact conditions are forecast each tide through to Wednesday morning 09/11/2022. This may cause minor impacts at each high water. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Avoid walking at the sea front or parking at Climping Street Car Park. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. We will update this message by 19:00 on 07/11/2022.

The River Arun is high and rising. In the last 24 hours 21mm has been recorded at Itchingfield. From 18:30 06/11/2022 minor flooding could affect grassy areas and gardens of Tanbridge Park and Blackbridge Court and possibly fields behind Arunside and playground of Arunside School. From 23:30 06/11/2022 minor flood impacts will affect fields and gardens of isolated mill properties between Broadbridge Heath and Pallingham Quay. From 06:00 07/11/2022 water could approach properties at Pallingham Lock. Most of the rain has now cleared to the east, but isolated showers are possible Sunday evening, continuing Monday and Tuesday. The river should begin to fall in Horsham by 01:00 07/11/2022, but nearer Pallingham will be higher than normal until midweek. We predict river levels could end up similar to Friday, perhaps higher at Pallingham. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Wanford, if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 11:00 07/11/2022.

Heavy rain has fallen over Essex and northeast London today, Sunday 6th November. River levels on the River Roding in Abridge, Buckhurst Hill and Loughton are rising.  

There is likely to be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river today.  Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur.

The river is likely to continue rising slowly for the rest of the day. There is more light rain forecast over the next 24 hours but not as heavy as the rain earlier today, Sunday 6th November.

We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff on standby to attend to any blockages in the river.
This message will be updated at 9am tomorrow, Monday 7th November, or as the situation changes.

Heavy rain has fallen over Essex and Hertfordshire today, Sunday 6th November. River levels are rising on the River Roding in the Molehill Green, Dunmow, Ongar, Fyfield, High Ongar and Stapleford areas.

There is likely to be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river today.  Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur.

The river is likely to continue rising slowly for the rest of the day. There is more light rain forecast over the next 24 hours but not as heavy as the rain earlier today, Sunday 6th November. 

We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff on standby to attend to any blockages in the river.
This message will be updated at 9am tomorrow, Monday 7th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Cripsey Brook in Epping Forest District Council
items.message:
Heavy rain has fallen over Essex and Hertfordshire today, Sunday 6th November. River levels are rising on the Cripsey Brook in the Thornwood Common, North Weald Bassett, Moreton and Chipping Ongar areas.

There is likely to be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river today.  Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur.

The river is likely to remain high for the rest of the day. There is more light rain forecast over the next 24 hours but not as heavy as the rain earlier today, Sunday 6th November.

We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff on standby to attend to any blockages in the river.
This message will be updated at 9am tomorrow, Monday 7th November, or as the situation changes.
